This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: THE SOLDIER'S FUTURE.
div.p: "A great social problem" is Mr. Haldane's description of the difficulty of equipping the soldier for a civilian occupation after he leaves the colours, and of finding employment for the many thousands of men who annually enter the Reserves and are thrown upon the labour market.

It is a three-fold problem. It affects, in the first instance, the class and type of man who enlists in the land forces of the Crown. With all the endeavours of Army reformers to make the pay and conditions of service more attractive to the healthy and adventurous youth of the country, but little has been done officially in practical form to ensure a reason. able future to the man when he is no longer fed, clothed, and quartered by the State and has to make a fresh start with his liability as Reservist upon his shoulders. The result is an initial and constant difficulty in recruiting, excepting in times of acute industrial distress, and an unwillingness on the part of the most desirable kind of lad to join the colours, although in the last few years the general standard of the recruits has admittedly improved. Secondly, the problem involves the directing of the soldier's attention to his own interests, a proposition which may appear unmeaning, but which is a very real stumblingblock in the way, of all who are most diligently active for the men's welfare. Under present conditions a man enlists for a variety of reasons, but seldom enough with an eye to the future. He is in trouble in his village and "goes for a soldier"; or he does not like the employment to which he has been put; or trade is bad and he sees no chance of getting work. Of course, there are numerous exceptions to this generalization soldier families among the rank and file who in turn follow the colours as naturally and proudly as the oldest of our Naval or AngloIndian septs. But the average recruit, good man as he often turns out to be, has joined the Army he hardly knows why or how and with no very definite object in view. To open up a field of subsequent civilian employment for him demands of him a certain sacrifice of leisure, industry, and money in order that he may, while still serving, gain knowledge at work-shops and classes of technical instruction. Proverbially improvident and shortsighted, he forgets during the years of physical comfort while he is in the service the stress of life that awaits him on leaving the Army and he is not, with few exceptions, inclined to add to his routine military duties the self-imposed task of learning the rudiments of a civilian calling. In its third aspect the problem concerns the employers of labour.

The old, deep-seated prejudice against the soldier is dying out, but it dies hard. Many great employment concerns in the country systematically do their utmost to find places for the ex-Regular. Government Departments are in certain cases, notably that of the Post Office, under a definite agreement with the War Office as to the number of billets annually to be allotted to him; some of the railway companies make a point of taking on as many Reservists, as possible; a group of the greatest manufacturing firms of the country have numbers of old soldiers on their wages sheets..

These, however, are only the few broad avenues of regular employment into which a comparatively few fortunate and specially. fitted men are able to pass; the great bulk of the many thousands per annuin remain Mr. Haldane's great social problem. How to give the man during his period of service an adequate amount of civilian training, and, having done that, how to bring him into ready touch with the employer in need of his labour, formed the subject of an exhaustive inquiry carried out by a Special Committee under Sir Edward Ward in the earlier part of the year, whose recommendations have recently been published. ("Tribune")

div.head: The Palaos Thoft.
div.p: Three of the four thieves who ransacked the palace of Prince Aly Pasha Haidar have been arrested. They bad just thrown into the Ismailia Canal the silver articles they bed stolen when they were arrested.

div.head: Valuable Find at Tol Basta
div.p: Our Zagazig correspondents reports that Dative workmen employed on excavations at Tel Basts discovered golden vase and lowl and several precious stones. Upon the authority of the moodie the valuables were removed by an inspector of the Antiquities Department.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: Nine steamers transited the Canal on Octo-1 ber 2, and paid transit and passenger toll amounting to Pr. 210.912.02. of these ships, 4 were British, 1 Norwegian, 1 German, 2d Dateb, Apd 1 Tarkieh. Two were northward and even southward bound. The Canal receipts for October 1 were Fr. 298,144 76.

div.head: Alexandria Tranquillity.
div.p: Great antistaction is expressed on all sides owing to the decision of the Alexandria Municipal Commission to suppress the puissance of motor hooters being used on bioyles. Hence forward sesh hooters can only be used on bona fide motor oars. Bicyclists will have to content themselves with the more euphonious bells. Pigeon Shooting Case.

div.head: The Mixed Contravention Court of Cairo
div.p: sentenced the defendants, the Cairo Pigeon booting Club at Rod-el Farag, to a fine of PT.6 for allowing pigeon shooting to be carried op in their grounde. An appeal has book lodged. All over Europe the same pastime se permitted, and Harlingham was quite as | out of the way as Rod el large and yet pigeon shooting was permitted there by the police utforines in London, and was only stopped Becanje. the majority of the members of the Haylineham Clab where's gain it.

div.head: HouseBoat for Sudan Biologist. ..
div.p: The Hamburg and Anglo-American Nile - Steamer Company have just completed, for the Sudan Government, a hóase-boat for the use of the marine biologist at Port Sudan, who is employed on an examination of the pearl fisheries. The houseboat, which is 58 leet long by 16 feet wide, is fitted, in addition to living rooms, with a chemical laboratory. The vessel was towed to Sued by one of the Company's togs and tbare handed over to the Khedivial Mail Steamship Company who have undertaken to tow her down the Red Sea to Port Sadan.' In addition to the house-boat the Hamburg and Anglo-American Nile Com. the company has also built three sailing boats, 23 feet long, for the same service,

div.head:
THE MINISTRIES.
NEW WAR OFFICE
div.p: We understand that nothing has been definitely decided as to the future situation of the Ministries of Justice, Foreign Affairs, the

Interior, Publio Construction, and Finance. The 1 -Government bas considered the possibility of erecting new buildings on new sites, and Mukhtar Pasha's Palace and the Kasr el Nil Barracks with the adjoining parade ground have been suggested as suitable spots. But the Ottoman High Commissioner shows no anxiety, to leave his palace and nothing whatever has been decided as to the future of l of tbe Kasr el Nil Barrack

Lo fact as far as the five Ministries above li mentioned are concerned everything is in the air. The principle that three new buildings, one for the Ministry of Public Instruction, one for Justice and Foreign Affairs, and one for the Interior and Finance shall be erected hasil been admitted, the more readily sinoe the present buildings are by no means substantial, and require constant and considerable l. repair. Bat as to their new cite or the date of their commencement nothing has been selected 1 and nothing is known. They may be commenced within five years or in fifteen and none of i the sites favoured by common gossip may 1 have the honour of being selected.

On the other hand the drawings for a new li War Office have been completed the specifications are being prepared, and be foundation pita sunk. The new Diwan 2 Harbiya will be built almost at right angles to the present, Ministries of War and Public Works on the li line between the chemical laboratory and the Sudan Office. The latter building will be demolished and when the new War Office, in which the Sudan Office will be invaded, is completed, the Ministry of Public Works will occupy the present quarters of the War Office officials.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: His Highness is spending to-day st Montazah. He drove through Alexandria yesterday in company with Mantapba Pasha Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria. His Highness left Ras-elTin Palace at 4.30 p.m., and proceeded to Bidi Gaber station for Montazh.
The Khedive will come to Alexandria to morrow to attend prayer.
The Khediyah on landing yesterday morning I proceeded direct to Monte xeh with the Khe divial family
. H. the Khedive received yesterday in audience Prince Mohamed Aly, and Captain Blaker ey.
The Mabronses on the voyage from Cou stantinople to Alexandria was under the command of Hasran Ibady Bey, A.D.C. to his Highness.

div.head: CHERIF PASHA ESTATE.
div.p: In the Mixed Court of Probate, before Judge Vasquez y amor, osme op for hearing yesterday morning the suit brought by the widow' (nee Colombani) of the late Mohamed Pasha't Cherit, ex Under Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs, who died in Paris, in August, praying 1 for the appointment of a judicial executor of the estate of the deceased, of which she was entitled to one-third, by an eilam sharieh of the Court. The defendant is Ibrahim Bey Cherif, who as son of the opole of the deceased Pasha, claims right of inheritance, a claim which is contested in the present litigation.

The defendant opposes the legality of the appointment by the Mixed Tribunal of such an executor, and on the plea of its incompetence, demanded that such appointment be made by the Native Court, on the ground that all the heirs were Ottoman subjects, and that the Crédit Foncier, with which the estate was hypothecated, had no actual interest. Defendant also opposed the appointment of Moharrem Pasha Ibrahim, and pot forward other dominees. | The case of the plaintiff is supported by all the other relatives of the deceased, viz., the mother of the deceased, who is widow of the celebrated Charif Pasha. Frangori, one time Premier and Regent, his sisters Dames Mobarrem Pasha Shahin and Abdelrabim Bey Sabri, as also the Crédit Poncier Egyptien.

Por the plaintiff Maitre Carton de Wiart contested the Ottoman nationality of his 1 client, which was not established in jurisprudence, citing article 19. of the Civil Code and the Law of 1863 ; and that the Mixed Tribunal was alone competent to grant probate, in view of the fact that the estate was hypothecated with the Crédit Foncier. Moltres Goarjon and Nassif represent the heirs, Maire Wissa Was
sif, Ibrahim Bey, defendant, M.Itre Chalom and y the Crédit Foncier.

div.head:
MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL.
LETTER TO FARID BEY.
div.p: A few days ago the Havas Agency telegraph ed from Paris that Mustapha Pasba Kamel had written to Farid Bey suggesting the formation of a National University, which would unite all Egyptians and strengthen the national sentiment. The following is the letter:

"My dear Farid Bey, "I have just heard through "Al Lowa" that & committee has been formed at Cairo for the purpose of opening a public subscription in order to offer me a banquet as a testimony of the satisfaction felt by Egyptians for the services I have rendered to my beloved country. I learn, on the other hand, that you have undertaken to act as treasurer for this committee. Allow me to ask you to communicate to the members of the committee and to those who have been good enough to accept their invitation my warmest thanks for the sym. pathie kindness they have shown towards a man who thinks that what he has done is a mere drop in the ocean of duty incumbent on every Egyptian. For my part I never in my ļife believed that I was worthy of such a mark of esteem or of gratitude for my champion ing of the rights of Egypt, for the struggle I have waged for its freedom and for my appeals to the patriotism of the Egyptiane. I have simply fulfilled a snored daty, and it is only to day that I have made the first steps towards conducting our beloved country towards the goal of prosperity. What then is the need of my merit, since the humblest soldier in an army displays to the whole world the noblest lesson and the noblest example Is it pot he who carries the standard of his country! Is it not he who defends its honour, its prestige and its independence, and who is the first to lay down his life in order to save the lives of millions of old men, women, and children 1

If such be the position of each member of an army how many ard how great are the duties, which we owe to our native land. We have enjoyed its benefits,--we who have received an intellectual education, and who are | conscious of all our obligations and who have bebeld the light of truth twinks before our) eyes; who have contemplated the greatness of civilised nations and who are perforce obliged! to acknowledge their greatness and our inferiority. I am infinitely obliged to you, but I cannot bring myself to accept mark of esteem and favour which I do not deserve, and I refuse to allow that a man can be rewarded for his patriotism, as if devoid of that noble feeling he cannot be called a man. I am well aware that you desire to invoke the splendid ides of our native land through my poor personality, and that you wish to raise her i standard in your hands, for it is only this idea

and this sentiment which in reality 'my foes and my adversaries are fighting. But be not afraid | The object of your hopes is attained, for the banner of Egyptian patriotism floats majestically despite every calumny and every assault. The whole world has now learnt that the sap of life flows in our veins, and that we are eager to obtain glory in advancing along the right path. The whole world is convinced that We seek life and want a legitimate and legal constitution and freedom. The entire world has been convinced that what we want is the happiness of our country by means of education, labor, and reason. Buch a result was never anticipated by the enemies of Egypt and the Egyptians after that it had been generally believed that the question of Egyptian independence bad beep buried, and that quietened Boglish diplomacy.

And it is thus that I suggest to you the ides of a far greater gift that we can offer to our dear country. May the appeals of your committee sound throughout Egypt, and go straight to the heart of all Egyptians, We desire to fogod a National University which will shelter the children of the rich and the poor. This University will give us men strong and sincere, men fearless of menace, and who will brave chastisement; physicians and apostles who will hell and teach in turn, Sgoh is the anique gift worthy to be offered to Egypt by ber true patriots ; such the great present that will fill the soul with life, and sound the transports of felicity; such the imperious demonstration of life and sentiment, May factiong forget their strife, and the Prese unite; may animosity disappear, at least for a day, and may the harmony of anion be heard in all its splendour; may the nation consolidate - for bigger interests are at stake ! May all remember. ber that amongst these children of the poor whom the Occupation has covered from light and learning, there are great minds.
Encircled by the acreole of science, they might have been the glory of Egypt. May those who love and feel remember that in our midst there are treasures hidden ; there tres
ures will flood the earth with their splendor; they shine, but they are buried in the soil of

be poor. What would be my happiness and my joy if one day I might lay one stone in the crest edifice of our University, in company with the e august workers who labour only for good, and who desire neither reward nor favour .

div.head: THE KAMEL BANQUET.
div.p: Most decidedly our Nationalists do not all love the Kameloorsey. "Al Minbar" publishes a letter, signed "Said Bosa," the author of which, so far from announcing his intention of appearing at the banquet in honour of the patriot, states that he would prefer to see Mustapha's rich friends devoting their cash to adacational objects instead of wasting money on a copious bar quet which will have no effect whatever. Evidently the feast will be sump taons, and we may expect the communicative beat with which M. Pelletan has made 08 Familiar to kindle the permanence of the banqueters into a perfect consortium of indiscretions.

div.head:
PILGRIMS AND PLAGUE
THE SUEZ OUTBREAK.
div.p: Sinos the 7th Jaly up to yesterday there have been 34 deaths out of 49 Chaos of bubong To plague at Snez. Ten of the patients have i recovered and five still remain under treatment. The outlook for the pilgrims is serious, as Constantinople has taken alarm, and the Ottoman Quarantine Council yesterday in.fi

released the period of quarantine at Kamaran bu to five days for all persons starting from Baer. The Quarantine Board at Alexandria has asked the Ottoman Coanoil to allow the pilgrims to be submitted to quarantine at Tor instead of at Kamran.
To-day's bulletin apnouno99 two more fatal 4868 of plsgae at Saez and one fresh case admitted into hospital.

A Greek woman, of the Midan quarter, and an Italian woman, of the Hamamil district, were admitted to the Government hospital at Alexandria yesterday. Three of the plague patients at the hospital were discharged poured yesterday.
The following telegrams have been received by the Ottoman Dalegate on the Quarantine Board from the Ottoman Council: -
Pére, 8 Octobre 1906. Navires avec pelerios ou voyageurs à Baez poor Yambo Djeddah 6 jours désinfection dératisation.
Navires sans pèlerin, voyageurs Saea 48 høres, désinfeotion, dératisation.
Navires Sues destination Méditerranée 48 heures désinfection dératisation.
Navires pèlerins transitant Capal saps y opérer, ni communiquer Suez pour Yambo, Djeddah visite médicale.

div.head:
THE LATE MAJOR JOHNSTONE.
MEMORIAL SERVICE.
div.p: A memorial service was held at 6 o'clock yesterday afternoon at All Saints' Church, Cairo, in memory of the late Major L'Estrange Johnstone, RE. Many friends and colleagues of the deceased officer were present, and nome ous wreaths had been gent and were arranged in the chancel of the oburoh. Amongst those present we may mention Lord Bdward Cecil, Mr. Parnell, Mr. Alban, Captain Blakeney, Mr. Verschoyle, and the greater portion of the European staff of the State Railways, li Skander Pashs Fehmy, most of the officers of the Royal Engineers who are at progent in Egypt, British, Turkish, and Keyptian officers of the Khedive's army, etc. The service was fully choral, and conducted by the Rev. Thomas Barns, and at the close of the congrega: tion rose for the rendering of the 'Dead March in Saal."

div.head: NEW VICTORIA HOTEL.
div.p: In view of the increasing popularity of this fashionable hotel, the energotio proprietor has decided to add a large wing to the present building to provide for upwards of sixty rooms. By this arrangement the main entrance will face doe South, a decided advantage; this will lead into magnificent vestibule to connect with the present dining hall, and it is contemplated to run a terrace over the strip of garden now in front of the hotel, the part now occupied by the main entrance being converted into a band stand. The work on the anoex, which is to begin in a fortnight, will in no wise interfere with the comfort or arrangements of the hotel which will remain open all winter, for which season special terms will be made. A motor car is shortly expected for the benefit of the hotel traffic. Both from its healthy position and its aristocratic surroundings, the new hotel is to be highly commended to tourists and residents.

div.head: A CASE FOR ENQUIRY.
div.p: "L, Journal du Caire" makes a statement which, it truro, demands the attention of the authorities. Oar confrère declares that three young Baropean girls were followed in the Mouski on Tuesday afternoon by a group of natives who made obeaune observations to them and even dared to lay hands on them. The police, it adds, turned their backs and remarked "No matter they are only Beropean women!" Should this statement be confirmed we trust severe example will be made of these extraordinary sba wishes. This is not the first time that an incident of this sort has been reported.

div.head: TANTAH AGRICULTURAL SHOW.
div.p: Two days ago, Hassan Pasba Radwan, Mudir of Gharbieh, left 'Tantab for Cairo in order to make farther preparations for the Tantah Agricultural Show, which will be held shortly on the 11th, 12th, and 13th inst.

div.head: K.R.RS. FOR ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The detachment of the 1st Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps, approximating a strength of four officers and 290 non commissioned officers and mon, which is to be stationed at Alexandria, will entrain at Cairo, Abbassieh siding, to-morrow. They will be quartered at Ras el Tin barracks. .

div.head:
THE MONEY FAMINE.
SCARCITY OF GOLD IN EGYPT.
div.p: Alexandria has been addenly denuded of gold within the last few days, and considerable inconvenience has resulted from this scarcity of the precious metal. The banks are consjug for the time being to advance money and great are the complaints therefore, as it is the firm on viction of everybody here, who has banking account, that they can overdraw to an unlimited extent. This present acute state of penury is due to the fact that cotton has gone to a very high price at the beginning of the season. It is true that such prices havo been seen before, but never at the opening of the season, and the result is that an enormous financial drain bas ensued. Growers find the present prices so very remunerative that they Are selling their cotton wholesale. The merchants naturally have to boy when the natives want to sell and the vendors insist on cash on delivery of their stocks in their own villages are at the ginning centres. Such a roh for money has never before been known at the Alexandrian banks as has taken place within the last tew days and as Alexandria is the cotton financing centre of Egypt, the stringency has been particularly acate bere, bat almost as severe a crisis is also being experienced in Cairo. The banks had amplo cash reserves for a normal demand up to a week ago, but pince Monday, week over £2,000,000 have been withdrawn here and sent to the interior in bard cash. Within the last three days the National Bank of Egypt at Alexandria has paid out £510,000, and the same sort of thing is the tale at every bank.
Half a million sterling is arriving at Alex andria on Monday next by the Austrian Lloyd steamer. This, however, is probably all earmarked already, so it will in no way relieve the situation.
It was rumoured that half a million was on board the Isis, bat this is probably ontree, as all shipments of money from Bogland come by way of Trieste

A very satisfactory symptom of the healthy financial condition of the country deserves to be noted, and that is that at the present janctare the Boarse keeps very firm and despite the keepest need for gold, nobody finds himself so bard pat to it as to realise to any serious extent.

Some are inclined to find fault with the banks, for it is argued that it had been known for some time before that the season was going to open at high prices and that natives would avail themselves of the occasion to sell, but although the banks made some provision 2 it has proved quite insufficient and that a little foresight should have enabled them to lay in much bigger stocks of money. But in justice to the banks it must be remembered that there have been times when owing to the willingness of growers to realise their orops the banks have found themselves running op *, heavy bill for interest to no purpose. Others lay the blame on the Government, but we really fail to see that the Government have got anything to do with the case.

There is, however, one direction in which the Government might take steps to do something to mitigate any feature stringency. Very large payments are due on account of the land tax in October, November, and December. These months are chosen as at this time of the year the follab has plenty of money. It might be possible to enforce a less cumbersome form of machinery for getting this money back into circulation again. The Moodirieh authorities and the Caisse de la Dette koop this amount much too long a time out of circulation.

div.head:
THE ISIS BREAKDOWN.
ARRANGEMENTS FOR MAILS.
div.p: Various are the ronsons assigned to the non-arrival of the P. and 0. mail-bont Isis, and we are unable to obtain any absoluto confirm
tion of any of the rumours afloat. That ber I engines broke down is certain, but whether

due to arch an explosion as is reported by Router's telegram of yesterday's data we cannot say. Most of our readers know the Isis as one of the two twin ships which do the weekly service from Port Said to Brindisi, and which carry the most important maile for and from England. She was built in 1899 and has
gross tonnage of 1,728 with horsepower of 6,500. The maximum speed attainable by the Isis and Osiris is said to be 91 koote, bot, we believe, they do not exceed 18 knots an hour Na rale.

It cannot be stated definitely when the maila will be received. We hear that the Persia, which arrived at Port Said on Tuesday, has gone to the Isis to take off her mails and passengers. The ustal Brindisi weekly outward mail will be carried next week by the Arcadia due from India on Sunday night, and that requal will afterwards go on to Maravillos.
Athens, October 3. The Peninsular and Oriental stemmer Lois bas put into Zsnto, having lost her propeller. She is also leaking.
(Router)

ZANTE, October 3. The laia was carrying the Indian mail. Bbo is looking badly. The captain has telegraphed for a man o war and for divoro. A cylinder borst and the propeller screw broke and fell into the son. The table in the smoking room above the engines were blown into the air. Several persone had hair breadth copo. Nobody was hurt.
(Router)
MALTA, October 8. The cruiser Saffolk he left to assist the Lais.
(Reuter)

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE

La plupart d'entre elles font dos diffioultés pour les avances sor titres et quelques unes renvoient à landi pour le paiement des ohèques. div.head: IRON IN EGYPT.
div.p: BY BENNETT H. BROUGH.

The period of the first area of iron in ancient Egypt has been warmly discussed. Some contend for its use in mythological times, while others would bring it as late as 600 B C., and disregarding all evidence of the discovery of iron remains, insist that stone, copper, and bronze tools were used exclusively up to that date, even in the building of the pyramids. These wonders of the world, the graves of Bzyptian kings, were built 8,000 years before Christ. Herodotus tells of the building of the Great Pyramid, stating that 100,000 men were employed for 20 years ; and be expressed woDder at the amount that must have been spent on their board and loathing, and on the iron with which they worked." The accuracy of the statements of Herodotos is borne out by the present condition of the Great Pyramid, which is built of granite blocks from the upper Nile, lined with slabs of normality limestone from Arabia. The magnificent temple at Thebes and the obelisks of a later period afford striking evidence of the technical skill, mathematical knowledge, and exóellent tools possessed by the ancient Egyptians.

That iron was known to the Egyptians, even in the earliest times, is evident from their conspicuous metallurgical knowledge, and from the facts that the working of granite and porphyry is scarcely conceivable without steel tools, that the oldest tombs have inscriptions referring to iron, and that sources of supply of manganiferous iron ore were found by Prof. Banerman in Upper Egypt. All possible doubt has been removed by remarkable archæologioal discoveries. An iron sickle, found by Belzoni under the feet of one the spbirxes at Karnak, is deposited in the Briti-b maroon, and proves that the smith's art was practiced at about 600 B.C. In 1887 a fragment of a wrought-iron tool was found in blasting operations in the Great Pyramid. This piece of iron, nearly 5,000 years old, is also preserved in the British museum. Analysis showed it to contain a small proportion of nickel ; bot as it also contained combined carbon, it was not of meteoris origin. In the British museum there is also exhibited « lamp of what is now iron rust, which was found, wrapped up in a fabrio with a mirror and tools of copper dating back to 3300 to 3100 B.C.

Much of the metal used in Egypt was imported as finished material from Ethiopis, and later from Phoenician merobants. Indeed, it is probable that Ethiopia was the largest centre of iron manufacture. The illustrations preserved of Egyptian iron manufacture show that the process was precisely the same as that still obtaining among Bhiopian races. On a stone, preserved at Florence, a negro slave is depiated working bellows from which the blast is conveyed by a bamboo pipe to a shallow pit in which the iron is smelted. In a second illustration is shown the forging of the iron by hammering it with a rounded stone on a stone anvil with wooden base. It is clearly proved | by pictures on Bgyptian tombs that bellows

were in ore in the fifteenth century B.C. This shows distinct advance over the primitive method of smelting on a windy hillside ; and it is curious to note that even at the present day terraces with a natural sir draught are used for lead smelting in Bolivia,
An idea of the relative value of iron in the fifteenth century B. C, is given by the story told by Herodotas of the beautiful Rhodopis whe, having amassed great wealth in Egypt,

wi had to leave a memorial of herself in | Greece. She therefore determined to have something made, the like of which was not to be found in any temple, and to offer it at the shrine at Delphi, So she set apart a tenth of her possession, and purchased with the money a quantity of iron spits, such as are fit for roasting an ox whole, which she presented to the oracle. Rhodopis lived in Egypt in the reign of Amasis (570 to 526 B. C.).

div.head: WHERE ASSASSINS ARE REVERENCED.
div.p: A correspondent of the "Times" who, in bus travels through Rapsia, has moved among all classes, says that the cherished possession in many houses was an album containing photographs of assassins. A girl of seventeen called her collection bør "pantheon." On its first page was a picture representing a girl thrusting into the hands of her lover & revolver with which be was to go forth and assassinate. Then followed photographs of Kalayeff, who assassinated the Grand Dake Serge, of 8c zooc ff, who assassinated Plebve, and of many others--& Bassins all. There was also an extract from a letter written in prison by Mario Spiridonova, who killed M. Luzhanofsky, the Vice Governor of Tamboff. On the fly leaf of the album was written in English :
Lives of great ones all remind me I can make my life sublime.

div.head: PRISONERS OF THE HAREM.
div.p: Disenchanted." By Pierre Loti. Translated by
Clara Bell. Londoa : Macmillan. 6s.

Three beautiful Turkish girls, all very young, though one is already a divorced wife, beg the ditingaiebed antbor, André Lbéry, to write an ad account of their sufferings that will touch the heart of the western world. André Lbéry is all Frenchman, who in his youth lived in Constantinople, and who returns at long intervals to visit the grave of a Circassian girl whom once | he loved. Some readers of M. Loti's works may well feel rathore weary of this grave, and of the carefully worded sentiment that has been poured upon it in more than one of his books. | The grave it found neglected and defaced, and

Lbéry lingers in Constantinople in order to have it secretly repaired and given into the keeping of some friendly Moslem. While he is carrying out this pious work mysterious letters come to him from an unknown lady who has admired his books about the dead Ciroassian, The letters lead to a meeting where three veiled and black-robed figures ask him for his friendship and beg bim to regard them as "souls," and not as women, since he will never see their faces. Many repetitions of this meeting and more letters from the back of a story that I would be intolerably monotonous except for the really interesting pictures of what one might call "upper class" barem life.

All who know anything of Turkey are aware that behind the shutters of a harem are often to be found cultivated women of western civilization, who in appearance and manners might belong to London or Paris, and in education often surpass the daughters of the West. Bat M. Loti exaggerates when he writes as if this state of things were the rale. It is as yet exceptional, and, perhaps, happily 80. Education without liberty and freedom of thought that can never be applied in action lead to very great unhappiness. The heroine of this tale, Djenam, bas every pleasure and luxury that wealth can command except personal liberty. M. Lüti's sympathetic imagination enables him to do soribe in a most moving way her state of mind when she realizes that her girlhood is over, and that she is on the eve of marriage with a man whom she has ever seen. He describes the mockery of the marriage ceremony where the poor little bride sits on approved for a whole day, forced by etiquette to mile without ceasing, while all the women of thy town press round her with congratulations that they know to be false. Here he brings out the curious fatalistic camaraderie of Eastern women. It is their lot to be unhappy, they will not resist; but they keep each other's secrets and help each other's intrigues. Man is merely the master and enemy. Yet in this story, though it would have been possible for Lhéry's three "souls'' (they de, however, unveil before the end) to escape,
they are too "proud," prefer to endure, even I to die, and merely ask him to make known the eltims of the educated Moslem women,

The maximum they claimed was that they should be regarded to a greater extent as thinking, free and responsible beings; that they should be allowed to see certain mon in their homes, veiled, if it were insisted on, but to talk to them- especially if there was any question of marriage. "With these," said Djanem, "we would rest satisfied for at least half a century, till a more
advanced stage in our evolation," -M. Loti thinks there is no desire to set aside the Koran, bat only to interpret it more kindly.

The book is full of those descriptions of ho Bast, those long drawn ecstasies of grief which we all expect to find in M. Loi's writing. But in ordinary businesslike English much of his hopied morbidity is lost. Miss Clara Bell has many good touches in her translation, as when she speaks of "villas built by delirious Levantines"-expression which calls op vividly the rooooo suburbs of Turkish towns. But she does not get Loti's spirit into her pages. Probably no writer is more tempting to translate and more difficult. Olay an artist in words as deliberate and conscious as himself could reproduce his penoliar atmosphere. And with him the form is more important than the matter, Even his touchee of sympathetic insight depend more on the words used than on the thought ex. preseed.

div.head: THE THRIFTY ITALIAN ABROAD.
div.p: The American Consul at Rome says that the <mount of money transmitted to Italy by Italians in the United States in 1905 was £871,973, an increase over 1904 of £8 982 ; from Canada £1253, an increase of £1,392 ; from Brazil £86,716, a decrease of £59 617 ; and from Argentins, an increase of £60,890. Besides these remittances other soms convert. ible in savings bank deposits were remitted in 1905 to an extent of £411,436.

div.head: DOG ENTOMBED 26 DAYS.
div.p: A dog belonging to a Guildford lady was rezoned from a rabbit warren, where it bad been entombed, without food or drink, for 96 days. The animal bad, apparently, chased a rabbit down a large hole. No trace of her was found antil Sunday, when her mistress, bappen 'ing to pass in the direction of the borrow, heard whines proceeding from it. Another dog, poticing the sounds, made for the rabbit hole immediately. Two men were called, and were not long before bey came upon the dog -- nothing but skin and bone, bør ribs prj-voting painfully onder ber black and tan cont. She is now "progressing favourably."

div.head: WEIGHTS AND MEASURES.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, I noticed in yesterday's issue of the "Egyptian Gazette" most interesting and interactive article on the great problem of weights and measures in Alexandria. It is not difficult to see that the writer of the article

in question was a devout follower of M. Zouro. | Although I, in common with all other Alex andrians, deeply regret that gentleman is no longer a member of the Alexandria Municipality, in reference to this matter I am sorry to differ from his point of view. M. Zouro holds that nothing has been done since. But be evidently forget that Mr. Mitchell Innes came down here specially in order to attend a meeting of the Municipality and gave the views of the Egyptian Government to the Municipal Councillors and the representatives of the various European Cham-1 bers of Commerce at Alexandria. In the discussion that followed it was unanimously decided that the best course to take would be to establish the metrical system. This meeting took place about four months ago and, as it was then the beginning of the annual exodna, it was decided to hold over the discussion until such time as all the different corporations, interested in this vital question should have their full complement of members in order to arrive at a definite and satisfactory solution. It is to be hoped that a representative gathering will then be convoked in order to deal with this | most important matter, for the laxity now prevailing in regard to weights and measures in Alexandria has become a very serious scandal, I am, Sir, Your obedient servant

div.head: CAIRO STREETS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,- A few words in your colomps, about the dangers to which pedestrians are subjected owing to the present state of the Cairo streets will, I hope, attract the attention of the responsible authorities.

Firstly, the roadways are being widened at the expense of the pavements which are becoming mere side-walks. I refer especially to | Sharia Kasr el Aïni, where on either side of the road, which is miles long, it is only possible to walk in single file.

Secondly, in the almost innumerable places where building is going on considerable stretches of the sidewalks are so encumbered with building material that the foot passenger must make use of the road and risk his neck among the ungoverned streams of arabia which rash along.
Thirdly, ramparts of stones and sand for road making are piled up in the middle of the roads, as, for instance, the Opera Square.

Fourthly, after dark some shops have electric lights outside of a laish-red tint, the brilliancy and unsteadiness of which dazzle pedestrians when crossing the road and these are in the most crowded thoroughfares.
Fifthly, in several places, especially at crossings (eg, round the Ezbekieh Gardens) side-walks and roadways are op for repair of) gas pipes without any sufficient protection.

Sixthly, the training season for horses has begun. There are numberless borae-dealers driving about at reckless pace horses which are being broken in. What with these, trams, motor-cars, and motor busses the pedestrian's lot is not a happy one. The fact is that no one who is someone is expected to walk and for the rest it does not matter-80 think the authorities.-Yours truly,
OFFICIALS AND CIVILIANS. TO THE EDITOR OF THE "Eayptian GAZETTE."

Sir, I have read with great care the letter of Civilian Official" from the Fayoum and also the violent reply to that letter, and I must confess that the letter of "Civilian Official" seems to have hit the mark pretty well, and that the violent reply that it has provoked leaves all his argaments quite unrefuted. Firstly I must remind "Ex Officio" that because a civilian official happens to write from the Payoum it does not prove that he is not frequently in Cairo and other places where he may have ample opportunity of bearing the topics of the day disonseed. I for one heartily associate myself with the statement that the letters in question have occured vast amusement to "Officials" and "The Common Commercial Herd" alike. Possibly sensitive members of that "herd," for reasons best knows to themselves, are unwilling to recognize these remarks as a "draw" only. The accusation of snobbishness brought against "Another resident of 2) years', standing, bat not an official" bas met with no 'reputation because the accusation is a just one. The main arguments of "Civilian Official" to the effect that refinement is not the outcome of any particular form of education are also wisely avoided in the violent ropley, because the arguments admit of no refutation. Again "Civilian Official" pointed out the error of making any distinction between "Civilian" and

Official." "This being also irrefutable his oppopept Again showed his wisdom in leaving this statement alone and in devoting himself to a not very edifying exhibition of insulting all effi isle because he felt that the commercial class in this country bad rot met with the respect it deserved at the bands of some anonymous writer. 1. During the occupation of this country by The Briti-b, the ror-official olass has not often had to complain of the vulgar and uncourteous behaviour of British officials. Is it possible that an early disappointment at some tar off dato, at which the attacker would have liked to have left the "common herd," can account for the violent and unseemly way in which be attacks bie fellow-country men who coonry Government posts in the Khedive's service ?
Yours eto.,
